questions.question: Select the wrong sentence:

options.label: ‡¶ï
options.text: Honey is sweet when it is tasted

options.label: ‡¶ò
options.text: Let a shirt bought for me

questions.option_a: Honey is sweet when it is tasted
questions.option_d: Let a shirt bought for me
questions.explanation: ‡¶è‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá ‡¶∏‡¶¨‡¶ó‡ßÅ‡¶≤‡ßã ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶á passive voice ‡¶è‡•§ ‡¶ò ‡¶®‡¶Ç ‡¶è, Buy me a shirt ‡¶è‡¶∞ (passive) ‡¶π‡¶ø‡¶∏‡ßá‡¶¨‡ßá ‡¶∂‡ßÅ‡¶¶‡ßç‡¶ß ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá Let a shirt be bought for me. Rule: Let + object ‡¶ï‡ßá subject + be + ‡¶Æ‡ßÇ‡¶≤ verb ‡¶è‡¶∞ past participle form + ‡¶â‡¶™‡¶Ø‡ßÅ‡¶ï‡ßç‡¶§ preposition (by/to/for) + subject ‡¶ï‡ßá object. The incorrect sentence among the options provided is: "Let a shirt bought for me." This sentence is grammatically incorrect because it lacks a subject and proper verb form. The imperative "let" is followed by a past participle "bought," which does not form a coherent imperative structure. A more grammatically correct version of this sentence would be "Let a shirt be bought for me" or "Buy a shirt for me." The other sentences are grammatically correct: "Honey is sweet when it is tasted" - This is a correct use of the passive voice. "Honey tastes sweet" - This is a correct simple present tense form. "Rice is sold cheap" - This is another correct use of the passive voice.

questions.question: After seeing the movie, _____________.

options.label: ‡¶ï
options.text: the book was read by many people

options.label: ‡¶ñ
options.text: the book made many people want to read it

options.label: ‡¶ó
options.text: many people wanted to read the book

options.label: ‡¶ò
options.text: the reading of the book interested many people

questions.option_a: the book was read by many people
questions.option_b: the book made many people want to read it
questions.option_c: many people wanted to read the book
questions.option_d: the reading of the book interested many people
questions.explanation: The correct answer is "many people wanted to read the book." Let's analyze why this is the best choice and why the other options are less suitable: The book was read by many people : This option uses the passive voice ("was read"), which makes it less direct and engaging than an active voice construction. It also doesn't clearly link the cause (seeing the movie) to the effect (people reading the book). The book made many people want to read it : This option is somewhat awkward and repetitive. It personifies the book by suggesting it had the agency to make people want to read it, which is a less natural way of expressing the idea. Many people wanted to read the book : This is the best option. It's straightforward, uses active voice, and clearly links the action of seeing the movie with the desire to read the book. The reading of the book interested many people : This choice is also a bit awkward. It unnecessarily nominalizes the verb "read" into "the reading," which makes the sentence more complex and less direct. It also doesn't make the cause-effect relationship as clear as option 3. So, "After seeing the movie, many people wanted to read the book" is the most clear and direct way of expressing the idea that the movie inspired an interest in reading the book.

questions.question: Charley Horse' means:
He told us _____ sad and that it would be better for everyone.
questions.explanation: - In English, when forming negative sentences or phrases, the word "not" is often used to indicate negation. - When using "not" with the verb "to be," it typically precedes the base form of the verb, which is "be" in this case. - Therefore, the correct construction is "not to be." Example: "He told us not to be sad and that it would be better for everyone." Here, "not to be" is used to indicate that the speaker is advising against being sad, and it follows the rule of using "not" with the base form of the verb.

(‡¶Ö‡¶•‡¶¨‡¶æ ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶ü‡¶ø‡¶á Present Tense-‡¶è)‡•§ ‡¶ó (Mason hates to ride his bike but loves swimming): ‡¶è‡¶ñ‡¶æ‡¶®‡ßá 'to ride' (Infinitive) ‡¶è‡¶¨‡¶Ç 'swimming' (Gerund) ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶∏‡¶æ‡¶•‡ßá ‡¶¨‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶¨‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶∞ ‡¶ï‡¶∞‡¶æ ‡¶π‡ßü‡ßá‡¶õ‡ßá‡•§ ‡¶™‡ßç‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶∞‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶æ‡¶≤‡¶ø‡¶ú‡¶Æ ‡¶Ö‡¶®‡ßÅ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡ßü‡ßÄ ‡¶¶‡ßÅ‡¶ü‡¶ø‡¶á ‡¶è‡¶ï‡¶á ‡¶´‡¶∞‡ßç‡¶Æ‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶§‡ßá ‡¶π‡¶¨‡ßá‡•§ ‡¶∏‡¶†‡¶ø‡¶ï ‡¶ó‡¶†‡¶®: Mason hates to ride his bike but loves to swim . IF 8x-5y+16=0 & x+3y-17=0, what is the value of y?
questions.explanation: 8 x ‚àí 5 y = ‚àí 16 ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ( i ) x + 3 y = 17 ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ( i i ) ( + ) 9 x ‚àí 2 y = 1 or, x = 2 y + 1 9 (ii) 2 y + 1 9 + 3 y = 17 or, 2 y + 1 + 27 y 9 = 17 or, 29 y = 153 ‚àí 1 ‚à¥ y = 152 29 \begin{array}{l}8 x-5 y=-16----(i) \\ \frac{x+3 y=17----(i i)}{(+) 9 x-2 y=1} \\ \text { or, } x=\frac{2 y+1}{9} \\ \text { (ii) } \frac{2 y+1}{9}+3 y=17 \\ \text { or, } \frac{2 y+1+27 y}{9}=17 \\ \text { or, } 29 y=153-1 \\ \therefore y=\frac{152}{29}\end{array} 8 x ‚àí 5 y = ‚àí 16 ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ( i ) ( + ) 9 x ‚àí 2 y = 1 x + 3 y = 17 ‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí ( ii ) ‚Äã or, x = 9 2 y + 1 ‚Äã (ii) 9 2 y + 1 ‚Äã + 3 y = 17 or, 9 2 y + 1 + 27 y ‚Äã = 17 or, 29 y = 153 ‚àí 1 ‚à¥ y = 29 152 ‚Äã ‚Äã

questions.question: If Y=8+X and 3Y=3+4X, what is the value of Y?
questions.explanation: 4 y = 32 + 4 x 3 y = 3 + 4 x ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí \begin{array}{c}4 y=32+4 x \\ 3 y=3+4 x \\ -\quad-\quad-\end{array} 4 y = 32 + 4 x 3 y = 3 + 4 x ‚àí ‚àí ‚àí ‚Äã y=29

questions.question: The length of a rectangle is four times of its width of the are is 100 m¬≤. What is the length of the rectangle?
questions.explanation: Let, Length = 4 x Width = x ‚à¥ Area, x √ó 4 x = 100 ‚áí x 2 = 25 ‚áí x = 5 ‚à¥ Length = 4 x = 20 \begin{array}{l}\text { Let, Length }=4 x \\ \quad \text { Width }=x \\ \therefore \text { Area, } x \times 4 x=100 \\ \Rightarrow x^{2}=25 \\ \Rightarrow x=5 \therefore \text { Length }=4 x=20\end{array} Let, Length = 4 x Width = x ‚à¥ Area, x √ó 4 x = 100 ‚áí x 2 = 25 ‚áí x = 5 ‚à¥ Length = 4 x = 20 ‚Äã

questions.question: calculate Sin(-585¬∞)
questions.explanation: sin ‚Å° ( ‚àí 585 ‚àò ) = ‚àí 1 2 \sin \left(-585^{\circ}\right)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} sin ( ‚àí 58 5 ‚àò ) = ‚àí 2 ‚Äã 1 ‚Äã

questions.question: Find the values, 1 ‚àí tan ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò 1 + sin ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò + sin ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò \frac{1-\tan ^{2} 60^{\circ}}{1+\sin ^{2} 60^{\circ}}+\sin ^{2} 60^{\circ} 1 + s i n 2 6 0 ‚àò 1 ‚àí t a n 2 6 0 ‚àò ‚Äã + sin 2 6 0 ‚àò
questions.explanation: Solve: 1 ‚àí tan ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò 1 + sin ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò + sin ‚Å° 2 60 ‚àò = 1 ‚àí ( 3 ) 2 1 + ( 3 2 ) 2 + ( 3 2 ) 2 } tan ‚Å° 60 = 3 sin ‚Å° 60 = 3 2 \left.\begin{array}{ll} \text { Solve: } \frac{1-\tan ^{2} 60^{\circ}}{1+\sin ^{2} 60^{\circ}}+\sin ^{2} 60^{\circ} \\ =\frac{1-(\sqrt{3})^{2}}{1+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2} \end{array}\right\} \begin{array}{l} \tan 60=\sqrt{3} \\ \sin 60=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \end{array} Solve: 1 + s i n 2 6 0 ‚àò 1 ‚àí t a n 2 6 0 ‚àò ‚Äã + sin 2 6 0 ‚àò = 1 + ( 2 3 ‚Äã ‚Äã ) 2 1 ‚àí ( 3 ‚Äã ) 2 ‚Äã + ( 2 3 ‚Äã ‚Äã ) 2 ‚Äã ‚é≠ ‚é¨ ‚é´ ‚Äã tan 60 = 3 ‚Äã sin 60 = 2 3 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã = ‚àí 2 1 + 3 4 + 3 4 = ‚àí 2 7 4 + 3 4 = ‚àí 8 7 + 3 4 = ‚àí 32 + 21 28 = ‚àí 11 28 \begin{array}{l}=\frac{-2}{1+\frac{3}{4}}+\frac{3}{4}=\frac{-2}{\frac{7}{4}}+\frac{3}{4} \\ =\frac{-8}{7}+\frac{3}{4}=\frac{-32+21}{28}=\frac{-11}{28}\end{array} = 1 + 4 3 ‚Äã ‚àí 2 ‚Äã + 4 3 ‚Äã = 4 7 ‚Äã ‚àí 2 ‚Äã + 4 3 ‚Äã = 7 ‚àí 8 ‚Äã + 4 3 ‚Äã = 28 ‚àí 32 + 21 ‚Äã = 28 ‚àí 11 ‚Äã ‚Äã

questions.question: xpress 0.24 into simple fraction
Two tailors X and Y are paid a total of Tk. 550 per week by their employer. If X is paid 120 percent of the sum paid of Y. How much is Y paid per week?
Two numbers A and B are such that the sum of 5% of A and 4% of B is two-thrird of the sume of 6% of A and 8% of B. What is A:B?
questions.explanation: 5 % A + 4 % B = 2 / 3 ( 6 % A + 8 % B ) ‚áí 5 A + 4 B = 4 A + 16 / 3 B ‚áí A = 16 ‚àí 12 3 B ‚áí A = 4 B 3 ‚áí A : B = 4 : 3 \begin{aligned} & 5 \% A+4 \% B=2 / 3(6 \% A+8 \% B) \\ & \Rightarrow 5 A+4 B=4 A+16 / 3 B \\ & \Rightarrow A=\frac{16-12}{3} B \Rightarrow A=\frac{4 B}{3} \\ & \Rightarrow A: B=4: 3\end{aligned} ‚Äã 5% A + 4% B = 2/3 ( 6% A + 8% B ) ‚áí 5 A + 4 B = 4 A + 16/3 B ‚áí A = 3 16 ‚àí 12 ‚Äã B ‚áí A = 3 4 B ‚Äã ‚áí A : B = 4 : 3 ‚Äã

questions.question: A class of 50 girls and 60 boys sponsored a football game. If 52% of the girls and 30% of the boys attended the game, what percentage of the class went to the game?
questions.explanation: Girls = 50 √ó 52 100 = 26 Boys = 60 √ó 30 100 = 18 In Percent = 100 √ó 44 100 = 40 % \begin{array}{l}\text {Girls }=50 \times \frac{52}{100}=26 \\ \text { Boys }=60 \times \frac{30}{100}=18 \\ \text { In Percent }=100 \times \frac{44}{100}=40 \%\end{array} Girls = 50 √ó 100 52 ‚Äã = 26 Boys = 60 √ó 100 30 ‚Äã = 18 In Percent = 100 √ó 100 44 ‚Äã = 40% ‚Äã

questions.question: A man has tk. 10,000 to invest. he invests tk 4000 at 5% and tk. 3500 at 4%. In order to have a yearly income of tk 500, he must invest the remainder at -
A bag contain five red balls, twelve blue balls, and eight green balls. If one ball is dawn from the bag, What is the probability that the ball will not be green?
questions.explanation: Red = 5 Blue = 12 Green = 8 \begin{array}{l} \text { Red }=5 \\ \text { Blue }=12 \\ \text { Green }=8 \end{array} Red = 5 Blue = 12 Green = 8 ‚Äã ‚à¥ \therefore ‚à¥ Probability 8 5 + 12 + 8 = 8 25 \frac{8}{5+12+8}=\frac{8}{25} 5 + 12 + 8 8 ‚Äã = 25 8 ‚Äã

questions.question: 11-[3+5 of (13-2‚úï+)]=?
questions.explanation: 11 ‚àí [ 3 + 5 of ( 13 ‚àí 2 √ó 6 ) ] = ? ‚áí 11 ‚àí [ 3 + 5 √ó 1 ] ‚áí 11 ‚àí 8 ‚áí 3 \begin{array}{l}11-[3+5 \text { of }(13-2 \times 6)]=? \\ \Rightarrow 11-[3+5 \times 1] \Rightarrow 11-8 \Rightarrow 3\end{array} 11 ‚àí [ 3 + 5 of ( 13 ‚àí 2 √ó 6 )] = ? ‚áí 11 ‚àí [ 3 + 5 √ó 1 ] ‚áí 11 ‚àí 8 ‚áí 3 ‚Äã

questions.question: Determine median from the following frequency distribution table: Time 30-35 36-41 42-47 48-53 54-59 60-65 Frequency 3 10 18 25 8 6
questions.explanation: Time Frequancy Cumulative Frequancy 30-35 3 3 36-41 10 13 42-47 18 31 48-53 25 56 54-59 8 64 60-65 6 70 Total n=70 Median Formula: Let, n 2 = 70 2 = 35 L = 48 ‚à¥ Median = L + ( n 2 ‚àí F c ) √ó h f m n = 70 F c = 31 f m = 25 h = 5 = 48 + .8 = 48.8 (Approx.) ‚âÖ 48.96 \begin{array}{l}\begin{array}{l|l}\hline \text { Median Formula: Let, } \frac{\mathrm{n}}{2}=\frac{70}{2}=35 & \mathrm{~L}=48 \\ \therefore \text { Median }=\mathrm{L}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{n}}{2}-\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{c}}\right) \times \frac{\mathrm{h}}{f_{\mathrm{m}}} & \mathrm{n}=70 \\ \mathrm{~F}_{\mathrm{c}}=31 \\ \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{m}}=25 \\ \mathrm{~h}=5\end{array} \\ =48+.8=48.8 \text { (Approx.) } \cong 48.96 \\\end{array} Median Formula: Let, 2 n ‚Äã = 2 70 ‚Äã = 35 ‚à¥ Median = L + ( 2 n ‚Äã ‚àí F c ‚Äã ) √ó f m ‚Äã h ‚Äã F c ‚Äã = 31 f m ‚Äã = 25 h = 5 ‚Äã L = 48 n = 70 ‚Äã = 48 + .8 = 48.8 (Approx.) ‚âÖ 48.96 ‚Äã L = 48 n = 70 F c = 31 f m = 25 h = 5 \begin{array}{l}\mathrm{L}=48 \\ \mathrm{n}=70 \\ \mathrm{~F}_{\mathrm{c}}=31 \\ f_{\mathrm{m}}=25 \\ \mathrm{~h}=5\end{array} L = 48 n = 70 F c ‚Äã = 31 f m ‚Äã = 25 h = 5 ‚Äã

questions.question: Two ships are sailing in the sea on the two sides of a lighhouse. The angle of elevation of the top of the lighthouseis observed form the ships are 30¬∞ and 45¬∞ respectively. If the lighthouse is 100 m high, the distance between the two ships is:
questions.explanation: Solve A B A C = tan ‚Å° 30 = 1 3 ‚áí A C = A B √ó 3 = 100 3 m A B A D = tan ‚Å° 45 ‚àò = 1 ‚áí A D = A B = 100 M ‚à¥ C D = ( A C + A D ) = ( 100 3 + 100 ) m = 273 m \begin{array}{l}\text { Solve } \frac{\mathrm{AB}}{\mathrm{AC}}=\tan 30=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{AC}=\mathrm{AB} \times \sqrt{3}=100 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{~m} \\ \frac{\mathrm{AB}}{\mathrm{AD}}=\tan 45^{\circ}=1 \Rightarrow \mathrm{AD}=\mathrm{AB}=100 \mathrm{M} \\ \therefore \mathrm{CD}=(\mathrm{AC}+\mathrm{AD})=(100 \sqrt{3}+100) \mathrm{m} \\ =273 \mathrm{~m}\end{array} Solve AC AB ‚Äã = tan 30 = 3 ‚Äã 1 ‚Äã ‚áí AC = AB √ó 3 ‚Äã = 100 3 ‚Äã m AD AB ‚Äã = tan 4 5 ‚àò = 1 ‚áí AD = AB = 100 M ‚à¥ CD = ( AC + AD ) = ( 100 3 ‚Äã + 100 ) m = 273 m ‚Äã

questions.question: The velocity of a boatrowed downstream is three times than that of the same boat rowed upstream. If the speed of the stream is 205 miles per hour, what is the speed of rowing in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: x + 3 x 2 ‚áí 2.5 + 3 √ó 2.5 2 ‚áí 2.5 + 7.5 2 ‚áí 10 2 = 5 \begin{array}{l}\frac{x+3 x}{2} \Rightarrow \frac{2.5+3 \times 2.5}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{2.5+7.5}{2} \Rightarrow \frac{10}{2}=5\end{array} 2 x + 3 x ‚Äã ‚áí 2 2.5 + 3 √ó 2.5 ‚Äã ‚áí 2 2.5 + 7.5 ‚Äã ‚áí 2 10 ‚Äã = 5 ‚Äã

questions.question: What is the 200th term of the series 2,5,8,11,14,........?
5+8+11+40+... if n‚Äôth term is 383, what is the value of n?
questions.explanation: n th n^{\text {th }} n th term = 1 =1 = 1 st term + ( n ‚àí 1 ) √ó +(n-1) \times + ( n ‚àí 1 ) √ó common Difference ‚áí 383 = 5 + ( n ‚àí 1 ) √ó 3 ‚áí 383 = 5 + 3 n ‚àí 3 ‚áí 3 n = 381 ‚áí n = 127 \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 383=5+(n-1) \times 3 \\ \Rightarrow 383=5+3 n-3 \\ \Rightarrow 3 n=381 \\ \Rightarrow n=127 \end{array} ‚áí 383 = 5 + ( n ‚àí 1 ) √ó 3 ‚áí 383 = 5 + 3 n ‚àí 3 ‚áí 3 n = 381 ‚áí n = 127 ‚Äã

questions.question: The ratio of seats for mathematics, physics and biology in a hool is 5:7:8 There is a proposal to increase these seats by 40%, 50% and 75% respectively. What will be the ratio of increased seats?
questions.explanation: Solve: M : P : B = 5 : 7 : 8 ‚áí 50 : 70 : 80 [Multiply by 10 ] Math = 50 √ó 40 / 100 = 20 Physics = 70 √ó 50 / 100 = 35 Biology = 80 √ó 75 / 100 = 60 New Ratio = 70 : 105 : 140 ‚áí 2 : 3 : 4 \begin{array}{l}\text { Solve: } M: P: B=5: 7: 8 \\ \quad \Rightarrow 50: 70: 80 \quad \text { [Multiply by } 10] \\ \text { Math }=50 \times 40 / 100=20 \\ \text { Physics }=70 \times 50 / 100=35 \\ \text { Biology }=80 \times 75 / 100=60 \\ \text { New Ratio }=70: 105: 140 \\ \Rightarrow 2: 3: 4\end{array} Solve: M : P : B = 5 : 7 : 8 ‚áí 50 : 70 : 80 [Multiply by 10 ] Math = 50 √ó 40/100 = 20 Physics = 70 √ó 50/100 = 35 Biology = 80 √ó 75/100 = 60 New Ratio = 70 : 105 : 140 ‚áí 2 : 3 : 4 ‚Äã

questions.question: The ratio between boys and girls in a class is 2:5. If boys leave and 4 girls join in the class, the ratio of the boys to the girls becomes 1:4. What is the orginal number of girls in the class?
questions.explanation: 2 x ‚àí 2 5 x + 4 = 1 4 ‚áí 5 x + 4 = 8 x ‚àí 8 ‚áí x = 4 ‚à¥ 5 x = 20 \begin{array}{l}\frac{2 x-2}{5 x+4}=\frac{1}{4} \\ \Rightarrow 5 x+4=8 x-8 \\ \Rightarrow x=4 \\ \therefore 5 x=20\end{array} 5 x + 4 2 x ‚àí 2 ‚Äã = 4 1 ‚Äã ‚áí 5 x + 4 = 8 x ‚àí 8 ‚áí x = 4 ‚à¥ 5 x = 20 ‚Äã

questions.question: If Log‚Çì (1/8)=-3/2, then is wgual to -
questions.explanation: Solve: log ‚Å° x ( 1 / 8 ) = ‚àí 3 / 2 \log _{x}(1 / 8)=-3 / 2 lo g x ‚Äã ( 1/8 ) = ‚àí 3/2 ‚áí x ‚àí 3 2 = 1 8 ‚áí x ‚àí 3 2 = 1 2 3 = 2 ‚àí 3 ‚áí x ‚àí 3 2 = 2 2 ‚àí 3 2 ‚áí x = 4 \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow x^{-\frac{3}{2}}=\frac{1}{8} \\ \Rightarrow x^{-\frac{3}{2}}=\frac{1}{2^{3}}=2^{-3} \\ \Rightarrow x^{-\frac{3}{2}}=2^{2^{-\frac{3}{2}}} \\ \Rightarrow x=4 \end{array} ‚áí x ‚àí 2 3 ‚Äã = 8 1 ‚Äã ‚áí x ‚àí 2 3 ‚Äã = 2 3 1 ‚Äã = 2 ‚àí 3 ‚áí x ‚àí 2 3 ‚Äã = 2 2 ‚àí 2 3 ‚Äã ‚áí x = 4 ‚Äã

questions.question: A number is 20 smaller than another 2/3rd of small number is equal to 1/4th of the larger numebr. What is the largest number ?
questions.explanation: Let, Larger number = x Smaller number = y x ‚àí y = 20 2 / 3 y = 1 / 4 x ‚áí 2 √ó 12 3 = 1 4 √ó 32 ‚áí 8 = 8 \begin{array}{l}\text { Let, Larger number }=x \\ \text { Smaller number }=y \\ x-y=20 \\ 2 / 3 y=1 / 4 x \\ \Rightarrow \frac{2 \times 12}{3}=\frac{1}{4} \times 32 \\ \Rightarrow 8=8\end{array} Let, Larger number = x Smaller number = y x ‚àí y = 20 2/3 y = 1/4 x ‚áí 3 2 √ó 12 ‚Äã = 4 1 ‚Äã √ó 32 ‚áí 8 = 8 ‚Äã
